Pictures]]|[[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]http://deadline.com/2011/05/mgm-sony-to-partner-on-21-jump-street-133320/}} | released = {{Film date|2012|03|12|[[South by Southwest|SXSW]]|2012|03|16|United States}} | runtime = 109 minutes{{cite web |title=21 JUMP STREET |url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/21-jump-street-2012-0 |publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] |accessdate=January 25, 2012 }} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $54.7 million{{Cite web|url=https://fastlane.louisianaeconomicdevelopment.com/Film/FilmSearchDetails.aspx?ProjNum=nJGmAz8vW35UYlT2oKXqig%3d%3d|title=21 Jump Street Budget Info|last=|first=|date=April 15, 2011|website=Louisiana Economic Development|publisher=|access-date=August 9, 2016}} | gross = $201.5 million{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=21jumpstreet.htm | title=21 Jump Street (2012) | website=[[Box Office Mojo]] | accessdate=October 23, 2012}} }} '''''21 Jump Street''''' is a 2012 American [[buddy cop]] [[Action film|action]] [[comedy film]] directed by [[Phil Lord and Christopher Miller]], written by [[Michael Bacall]], and starring [[Jonah Hill]] and [[Channing Tatum]].{{cite web |first=Kevin |last=Coll |date=December 21, 2009 |url=http://www.fusedfilm.com/2009/12/21-jump-street-film-gets-phil-lord-and-chris-miller-to-direct/ | title=''21 Jump Street'' Gets Phil Lord and Chris Miller to direct |publisher=Fused Film |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120218215845/http://www.fusedfilm.com/2009/12/21-jump-street-film-gets-phil-lord-and-chris-miller-to-direct/ |archivedate=February 18, 2012 |accessdate=June 13, 2014}} An adaptation of the [[21 Jump Street|1987–91 television series of the same name]] by [[Stephen J. Cannell]] and [[Patrick Hasburgh]], the film follows two police officers who are forced to relive high school when they are assigned to go undercover as high school students to prevent the outbreak of a new synthetic drug and arrest its supplier. The film was released theatrically on March 16, 2012 by [[Columbia Pictures]] and [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]], and grossed $201 million against a budget of $54.7 million. A sequel, titled ''[[22 Jump Street]]'', was released on June 13, 2014. Two further films, ''[[Jump Street (franchise)#Future|MIB 23]]'' (a crossover with the [[Men in Black (franchise)|''Men in Black'' franchise]]) and a female-led spin-off, are currently in development. ==Plot== In 2005, scholarly student Morton Schmidt ([[Jonah Hill]]) and popular underachieving jock Greg Jenko ([[Channing Tatum]]) miss their school prom; Schmidt being rejected by the girl he asked to be his date and Jenko being barred from attending because of his grades. Seven years later, the duo meets again at the Police Academy and become friends and partners on bicycle patrol. They catch a break when they arrest Domingo ([[DeRay Davis]]), the leader of a [[Outlaw motorcycle club|one-percenter]] motorcycle gang, but are forced to release him after they failed to read him his [[Miranda warning|''Miranda'' rights]]. The duo is reassigned to a revived scheme from the 1980s, which specializes in infiltrating high schools. Captain Dickson ([[Ice Cube]]) assigns them to contain the spread of a synthetic drug called HFS at Sagan High School. He gives them new identities and enrolls them as students, giving them class schedules fitting their previous academic performances; Jenko taking mostly arts and humanities, and Schmidt taking mostly science classes, but the duo mixes up their identities. Schmidt gets a lead on HFS from classmate Molly ([[Brie Larson]]), and he and Jenko meet the school's main dealer, popular student Eric ([[Dave Franco]]). The two take HFS in front of him to maintain their cover. After experiencing the drug's effects, the duo discovers that Schmidt's intelligence now makes him popular, while Jenko's lax attitude is frowned upon. Eric takes a liking to Schmidt, who develops a romantic interest in Molly. Jenko becomes friends with the students in his [[AP Chemistry]] class and finds himself becoming more interested in geeky hobbies and academic pursuits. Schmidt and Jenko throw a party at Schmidt's parents' house, where they are living during the course of their assignment, and invite Eric. During the party, a fight breaks out between Schmidt, Jenko, and some party crashers. Schmidt wins the fight, solidifying his social status and gaining Eric's trust. Jenko's friends hack Eric's phone to enable them to listen in on his conversations. At a party at Eric's house, using the phone hack, Jenko and his friends overhear information about an upcoming meeting between Eric and his supplier, but also catch Schmidt making disparaging comments about Jenko. The rift between the duo grows as their new school life intrudes upon their official police work. Schmidt and Jenko track Eric to a cash transaction with the distributors of HFS – the motorcycle gang from the park – and a chase ensues on the freeway. They return to school, argue, and eventually begin fighting, which disrupts the school play. They are expelled from school and are removed from the Jump Street program. Eric, stressed and terrified, recruits Schmidt and Jenko as security for a deal taking place at the school prom. While dressing for the prom, Schmidt and Jenko rekindle their friendship. At the prom, they discover that the supplier is the physical education teacher, Mr. Walters ([[Rob Riggle]]), who created the drug accidentally and started selling it to the students to supplement his teacher's salary. Having caught Eric smoking marijuana, he was able to persuade him into being his dealer. The motorcycle gang arrives for the deal but Molly interrupts them and starts arguing with Schmidt. As a result, the gang leader recognizes Schmidt and Jenko, and orders his men to kill them. Two of the gang members reveal themselves as undercover [[DEA]] agents Tom Hanson and Doug Penhall ([[Johnny Depp]] and [[Peter DeLuise]]), and former members of the [[21 Jump Street]] program. In the ensuing gunfight, Hanson and Penhall are fatally wounded. Mr. Walters and Eric escape with the money and Molly as a hostage; the gang, Schmidt, and Jenko follow close behind. Jenko creates a homemade bomb and uses it to kill the gang. Mr. Walters shoots at Schmidt but Jenko takes the bullet to his arm, sparing Schmidt's life. In response, Schmidt shoots Mr. Walters, unintentionally severing his penis. As they arrest Mr. Walters and Eric (in addition to successfully reading the Miranda rights), Schmidt and Jenko reconcile their relationship and Schmidt and Molly share a kiss. Both officers are congratulated and reinstated in Jump Street as Dickson gives them a new assignment: [[22 Jump Street|infiltrating a college]]. ==Cast== * [[Jonah Hill]] as Officer Morton Schmidt / Doug McQuaid, a socially awkward yet smart police officer. * [[Channing Tatum]] as Officer Greg Jenko / Brad McQuaid, a slow-witted yet handsome cop. * [[Brie Larson]] as Molly Tracey, one of Eric's friends and Schmidt's love interest. * [[Dave Franco]] as Eric Molson, a student who is one of the H.F.S. dealers. * [[Rob Riggle]] as Mr. Walters, a physical education teacher. * [[DeRay Davis]] as Domingo, the leader of the One-Percenters. * [[Ice Cube]] as Captain Dickson, a coarse police captain who manages 21 Jump Street. * [[Chris Parnell]] as Mr. Gordon, a drama teacher. * [[Ellie Kemper]] as Ms. Griggs, a science teacher who has a sexual interest towards Jenko and doesn't know he is a cop. * [[Jake Johnson]] as Principal Dadier, the principal of Sagan High. * [[Nick Offerman]] as Deputy Chief Hardy. * [[Holly Robinson Peete]] as Officer Judy Hoffs. * [[Lindsey Broad]] as Lisa. * [[Johnny Simmons]] as Billiam Willing-ham, a Sagan High student who died due to H.F.S. * [[Spencer Boldman]] as French Samuels * [[Rye Rye]] as Jr. Jr. * [[Caroline Aaron]] as Annie Schmidt * [[Dakota Johnson]] as Fugazy * [[Valerie Tian]] as Burns * [[Luis Da Silva]] as One-Percenter * [[Johnny Depp]] (uncredited [[Cameo appearance|cameo]]) as Tom Hanson{{cite web|last1=Weinstein|first1=Joshua|title=Johnny Depp '21 Jump Street' Cameo Came With Conditions (Spoiler Alert)|url=http://www.thewrap.com/movies/column-post/johnny-depp-21-jump-street-cameo-came-condition-36376/|publisher=The Wrap|accessdate=5 October 2014}} * [[Peter DeLuise]] (uncredited cameo) as Doug Penhall {{div col end}} ==Production== In May 2008, [[Sony Pictures]] confirmed that a [[film adaptation]] of the series was under development. [[Jonah Hill]] rewrote an existing script by screenwriter Joe Gazzam and executive produced the film, as well as starred in the film.{{cite web|url=http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2008/05/21-jump-street.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080514220832/http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2008/05/21-jump-street.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 14, 2008 |title=Jonah Hill in negotiations to develop '21 Jump Street' movie |last=Sperling |first=Nicole |date=May 13, 2008 |publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly|hollywoodinsider.ew.com]] |accessdate=February 25, 2009 }} Hill has said he wanted horror director [[Rob Zombie]] to direct the picture. In May 2009, Hill described the film adaptation as being an "R-rated, insane, ''[[Bad Boys (1995 film)|Bad Boys]]''-meets-[[John Hughes (filmmaker)|John Hughes]]-type movie".{{cite web |url=http://www.fusedfilm.com/2009/05/jonah-hill-talks-21-jump-street-remake-movie/ |title=Jonah Hill Talks 21 Jump Street Remake Movie |last1=Coll |first1=Kevin |date=May 28, 2009 |publisher=Fused Film |access-date=December 18, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120218215831/http://www.fusedfilm.com/2009/05/jonah-hill-talks-21-jump-street-remake-movie/ |archive-date=February 18, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} On December 21, 2009, it was announced that Sony was in talks with ''[[Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs (film)|Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs]]'' directing duo, [[Phil Lord and Christopher Miller]], to direct the film.{{cite web|url=http://www.fusedfilm.com/2009/12/21-jump-street-film-gets-phil-lord-and-chris-miller-to-direct/ |title=21 Jump Street Film Gets Phil Lord and Chris Miller To Direct |last=Coll |first=Kevin |date=December 21, 2009 |publisher=Fused Film |accessdate=December 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120218215845/http://www.fusedfilm.com/2009/12/21-jump-street-film-gets-phil-lord-and-chris-miller-to-direct/ |archivedate=February 18, 2012 |df=mdy }} The film follows the same [[continuity (fiction)|continuity]] as the TV series; Lord said, "So, all of those events of the original happened. And now here we are 20 years later, and we're watching it happen to different people."{{cite news | url=http://www.moviehole.net/201253416-clint-talks-to-21-jump-street-helmers-phil-lord-and-chris-miller | title=Clint talks to 21 Jump Street helmers Phil Lord and Chris Miller | work=Moviehole | date=March 20, 2012 | accessdate=March 20, 2012 | author=Caffeinated Clint}} However, the film features a highly comedic tone, departing radically from the more dramatic and earnest tone of the series.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/03/16/showbiz/movies/21-jump-street-review-ew/index.html |title='21 Jump Street': A fast, cheeky interpretation of the original |author=Lisa Schwarzbaum |work=CNN |date=March 16, 2012 |accessdate=April 9, 2012}} ===Filming=== The film was shot in and around the city of [[Metairie, Louisiana]] (suburb of New Orleans) in 2011, although the filmmakers took elaborate steps to disguise the location as a generic city named "Metropolitan City". They replaced distinctive street signs with signs using a [[Helvetica]] typeface, digitally removed billboards from local businesses (except the recognizable local [[New Orleans Regional Transit Authority|RTA]] signs toward the end of the film as well as a Zatarain's billboard ad), and avoided filming locations with iconic New Orleans imagery. Despite this, signature landmarks such as the [[Crescent City Connection]] and distinctive [[French Quarter]]–area street are still partially visible.{{cite news |first=Mike |last=Scott |work=[[The Times-Picayune]] |location=[[New Orleans, LA]] |title=A city undercover: New Orleans keeps a low profile in '21 Jump Street' |url=http://www.nola.com/movies/index.ssf/2012/03/a_city_undercover_new_orleans.html |date=March 18, 2012 |accessdate=March 18, 2012}} The main school used as the stand-in for the fictional Sagan High School was [[Riverdale High School (Jefferson Parish, Louisiana)|Riverdale High School]], located in [[Jefferson, Louisiana]].{{cite web|last=White |first=Cindy |url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/121/1218751p1.html |title=IGN Visits 21 Jump Street - IGN |publisher=Movies.ign.com |date=2012-02-15 |accessdate=2014-08-24}} The naked baby pictures of Hill's character used in the film were actual pictures of Hill as a child.{{cite news|work=[[Contactmusic.com]]|location=[[New York City, NY]]|title=Video - Jonah Hill: 'The Naked Baby Pictures In Jump Street Are Mine' - 21 Jump Street Press Conference Part 1|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/celebrity-videos/jonah-hill-the-naked-baby-pictures-in-jump-street-are-mine_11589|date=April 3, 2012|accessdate=June 1, 2012}} ===Music=== The score for the film was composed by [[Mark Mothersbaugh]]. In September 2014, it was released by La-La Land Records on a double disc album, limited to 2,000 copies. The second disc of the album also contains the score from the film's sequel, ''[[22 Jump Street]]'', composed by Mothersbaugh as well.{{cite web|title=Mark Mothersbaugh's Scores for '21 Jump Street' and '22 Jump Street' Released|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2014/09/23/mark-mothersbaughs-scores-for-21-jump-street-and-22-jump-street-released/|publisher=FilmMusicReporter.com|accessdate=1 November 2014}} A modernized cover of the original television's theme song by [[Rye Rye]] (who had a small part in the film) and [[Esthero]] was released as a single in the [[iTunes Store]].{{cite web|title=iTunes – Music – 21 Jump Street – Main Theme (From the Motion Picture "21 Jump Street") – Single|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/21-jump-street-main-theme/id509594047|publisher=[[iTunes]]|accessdate=1 November 2014}} In addition, a total of 21 songs were licensed for use in the film. The songs featured in the film include: {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * "[[The Real Slim Shady]]" – [[Eminem]] * "[[Police and Thieves]]" – [[The Clash]] * "You Can't Lose" – [[The Knux]] * "Boombox" – [[Simon Rex|Dirt Nasty]] * "Caesar" – [[Ty Segall]] * "[[Helena Beat]]" – [[Foster the People]] * "So Into You" – [[Atlanta Rhythm Section]] * "[[Party Rock Anthem]]" – [[LMFAO]] * "[[Straight Outta Compton (song)|Straight Outta Compton]]" – [[N.W.A]] * "Get Me Golden" – [[Terraplane Sun]] * "Swell Window" – [[Zee Avi]] * "Lookin' Fly" (feat. [[Will.i.am]]) – [[Murs (rapper)|Murs]] * "Rescue Song" – Mr. Little Jeans * "[[Graduation (Friends Forever)]]" – [[Vitamin C (singer)|Vitamin C]] * "Call the Police" – [[Ini Kamoze]] * "21 Jump Street – Main Theme (From the Motion Picture "21 Jump Street")" – [[Rye Rye]] & [[Esthero]] * "21 Jump Street (Main Theme)" – [[Wallpaper (band)|Wallpaper.]] * "You Are the Best" – [[Tim Myers]] * "Every Time I See Your Face" – Elon {{div col end}} ==Release== [[File:Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum - 21 Jump Street 027 - WonderCon 2012.jpg|thumb|Hill and Tatum promoting the film in costume at [[WonderCon]] 2012 in [[Anaheim|Anaheim, California]]]] The premiere of ''21 Jump Street'' took place on March 12, 2012, at the [[The Paramount Theatre (Austin, Texas)|Paramount Theatre]] in [[Austin, TX]], during SXSW.{{cite news| url=http://celebrity-gossip.net/21-jump-street/channing-tatums-sxsw-21-jump-street-premiere-593873| publisher=Celebrity-Gossip.net| work=| first=| last=| title=Channing Tatum's SXSW "21 Jump Street" Premiere| date=March 13, 2012| accessdate=March 13, 2012| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620083528/http://celebrity-gossip.net/21-jump-street/channing-tatums-sxsw-21-jump-street-premiere-593873| archive-date=June 20, 2012| dead-url=yes| df=mdy-all}} The film opened in a wide release in theaters on March 16, 2012. ''21 Jump Street'' grossed $138.4 million in the United States and Canada and $63.1 million in other countries for a worldwide total of $201.6 million; it is also the top-grossing high school comedy film of all-time. The film grossed $13.2 million on its opening day. During the weekend, the film grossed $35 million, taking ''[[The Lorax (film)|The Lorax]]'' out of the #1 spot that it held for its first two weeks.{{cite web|title= 'The Lorax' Defeats Disappointing 'John Carter'|url= http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3391&p=.htm|publisher= IMDB | work = Box Office Mojo|accessdate=March 11, 2012}} ''21 Jump Street'' was released on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] in Canada and the United States on June 28, 2012{{cite web|title=Canadian DVD Release Date |url=https://www.amazon.ca/21-Jump-Street/dp/B007T5RIM2/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1334626921&sr=8-5|accessdate=April 16, 2012}}{{cite web|title=American DVD Release Date |url=https://www.amazon.com/21-Jump-Street-Jonah-Hill/dp/B003Y5H5B0/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1334626921&sr=8-5|accessdate=May 11, 2012}} and was released in the United Kingdom on July 9, 2012.{{cite web|title=United Kingdom DVD Release Date |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Jump-Street-DVD-Channing-Tatum/dp/B005XZR4NI/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1334627016&sr=8-2|accessdate=April 16, 2012}} Some of the Blu-ray bonus features include 20 deleted scenes and "Johnny Depp on Set" explaining how they brought [[Johnny Depp]] to reprise his role as Tom Hanson. It was revealed that Johnny wanted his character to die, but for unknown reasons. In one of the deleted scenes, Tom and his partner, Doug Penhall, were shown to have survived the shootout. ==Reception== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], a [[review aggregator]], the film has an approval rating of 85% based on 213 reviews and an average rating of 7.2/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "A smart, affectionate satire of '80s nostalgia and teen movie tropes, ''21 Jump Street'' offers rowdy mainstream comedy with a surprisingly satisfying bite."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/21-jump-street-2011/ |title=21 Jump Street |publisher= Rotten Tomatoes ([[Flixster]]) |date= |accessdate=May 20, 2014}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 69 out of 100 based on 41 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web |url= http://www.metacritic.com/movie/21-jump-street | publisher= Metacritic ([[CBS]]) |title=21 Jump Street Reviews, Rating and Credits|date=March 16, 2012|accessdate=March 17, 2012}} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "B" on an A+ to F scale.{{cite web|url=https://www.cinemascore.com |title=CinemaScore |work=cinemascore.com }} Channing Tatum's performance was also lauded by critics. [[Richard Roeper]] of ''[[Chicago Sun-Times|The Chicago-Sun Times]]'' gave the film a grade of a B+ saying, "I didn't think we needed a ''21 Jump Street'', but it's actually kind of funny".{{cite web|url=http://www.richardroeper.com/reviews/21jumpstreet.aspx|title=21 Jump Street - RichardRoeper.com|work=richardroeper.com|accessdate=May 9, 2015}} ===Accolades=== {{Anchor|Awards}} The film was listed as the number 6 most illegally downloaded film of 2012 using the [[BitTorrent]] protocol with approximately 7.6 million downloads.{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/project-x-most-pirated-movie-of-2012-121227/ |title=Project X Most Pirated Movie of 2012 |first=Ernesto |last=Van Der Sar |publisher=[[TorrentFreak]] |work= |date=December 27, 2012 |accessdate=December 25, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DEF3Vfuv?url=http://torrentfreak.com/project-x-most-pirated-movie-of-2012-121227/ |archivedate=December 27, 2012 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} {| class="wikitable" style="width:99%;" |- ! Best Actor in a Comedy | Channing Tatum | {{nom}} |} ==Sequels and spin-offs== ===''22 Jump Street''=== {{main|22 Jump Street}} On March 17, 2012, Sony Pictures announced that it was pursuing a sequel to the film, signing a deal that would see Hill and Bacall return to write a [[Film treatment|script treatment]] that would be again developed by Bacall. Hill and Tatum returned to star in the film. They were executive producers as well, alongside producer [[Neal H. Moritz]].{{cite news|first1=Stuary |last1=Oldham |first2=Jeff |last2=Sneider |title=Sony books '21 Jump Street' sequel |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118051581?refCatId=13 |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=March 16, 2012 |accessdate=March 17, 2012}} Phil Lord and Christopher Miller returned to direct this sequel. The film was originally scheduled to be released on June 6, 2014.{{cite news| url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/men-black-4-21-jump-451611 | work=The Hollywood Reporter | first=Borys | last=Kit | title='Men in Black 4' in Development at Sony | date=May 3, 2013}} On May 8, 2013, it was announced that the film would be pushed back a week until June 13, 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=103977 |title=21 Jump Street 2 Takes Jurassic Park 4's Old Date |website=ComingSoon.net |date=2013-05-08 |accessdate=2013-09-28}} The film's title was ''22 Jump Street''.{{cite news|last=Chitwood|first=Adam|title=21 Jump Street Sequel Titled 22 Jump Street|url=http://collider.com/21-jump-street-sequel-22-jump-street/|accessdate=June 17, 2013|newspaper=Collider.com|date=June 5, 2013}} Like the first film, ''22 Jump Street'' received positive reviews. ===''23 Jump Street''=== On September 10, 2014, ''23 Jump Street'' was confirmed.{{cite web |url=http://screenrant.com/23-jump-street-movie-details-director/ |title='23 Jump Street' in the Works; No Director(s) Attached Yet |publisher=ScreenRant.com |date=September 10, 2014 |author=Chris Aga}} Channing Tatum has yet to sign on to the project. Tatum stated, "I don't know if that joke works three times, so we'll see."{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/channing-tatum-debates-23-jump-741625|title=Channing Tatum Debates '23 Jump Street': "I Don't Know If That Joke Works Three Times"|last=Lee|first=Ashley|date=October 17, 2014|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=January 25, 2015}} On August 7, 2015, it was revealed that Lord and Miller will not direct the film, but instead write and produce. A first draft of the film's script has been completed.{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/21-Jump-Street-Franchise-Needs-Find-Someone-Take-Over-75887.html|title=The 21 Jump Street Franchise Needs To Find Someone New To Take Over|last=Wakeman|first=Gregory|date=August 7, 2015|publisher=Cinemablend.com|accessdate=August 8, 2015}} In early 2015, a female-driven ''21 Jump Street'' film was rumoured to be in the works alongside the movie.{{cite news|title=Female-Driven 21 Jump Street Spinoff Rumored to be in the Works|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/435387-female-driven-21-jump-street-spinoff-rumored-to-be-in-the-works#/slide/1|work=comingsoon.net}} However, with the announcement of the ''Men in Black'' crossover and no further updates, the status of the film is unclear. ===''MIB 23''=== On December 10, 2014, it was revealed that Sony was planning a crossover between ''[[Men in Black (franchise)|Men in Black]]'' and ''Jump Street''. The news was leaked after [[Sony Pictures Entertainment hack|Sony's system was hacked]]{{cite news|last1=FRITZ|first1=BEN|title=Sony Plans 'Men in Black' – 'Jump Street' Crossover|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2014/12/10/sony-plans-men-in-black-jump-street-crossover/|accessdate=December 11, 2014|publisher=wsj.com|date=December 10, 2014}} and then confirmed by the directors of the films, [[Phil Lord and Christopher Miller|Chris Miller and Phil Lord]], during an interview about it.{{cite web|last1=Converse|first1=Simon|author2=Eric Eisenberg|title=M.I.B./Jump Street crossover unofficially confirmed|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Wait-Men-Black-21-Jump-Street-Crossover-Might-Actually-Happen-69170.html|publisher=Cinemablend|accessdate=2015-01-19|date=2015-01-14}}{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/3/4/11163926/report-23-jump-street-will-be-a-crossover-with-men-in-black|title=Report: 23 Jump Street will be a crossover with Men in Black|publisher=Polygon|last=Alexander|first=Julia|date=March 4, 2016}} [[James Bobin]] was announced as the [[Film director|director]] in March 2016.[http://io9.gizmodo.com/that-21-jump-street-men-in-black-crossover-is-actually-1762984300/ That 21 Jump Street-Men In Black Crossover Is Actually Happening]{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/04/13/trainspotting-2-elizabeth-banks-charlies-angels-jump-street-men-black|title=Sony confirms Charlie's Angels reboot, Jump Street-Men in Black crossover|publisher=entertainment Weekly|last=Franich|first=Darren|date=April 13, 2016|accessdate=April 13, 2016}} ===Untitled female-led spin-off=== A female-driven ''21 Jump Street'' film is being developed.{{cite news|title=Female '21 Jump Street' Spinoff in the Works|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/21-jump-street-female-spinoff-channing-tatum-broad-city-jonah-hill-1201484151/|work=variety.com}} In December 2016, [[Rodney Rothman]] was announced as the director and screenwriter for the film. Rothman returns to the franchise after co-writing ''22 Jump Street'', and ''MIB 23'' as well.{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/791137-21-jump-street-spinoff#/slide/1|title=Jump Street Spinoff Finds a Director - ComingSoon.net|date=December 1, 2016|work=comingsoon.net|accessdate=December 1, 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portalbar|2010s|Film in the United States|Comedy}} {{Commons}} * {{official website|http://www.21jumpstreet-movie.com/}} * {{IMDb title|1232829|21 Jump Street}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes |21-jump-street-2011}} * {{allrovi movie|511342|21 Jump Street}} {{21 Jump Street}} {{Phil Lord and Christopher Miller}} {{Teen Choice Award Choice Movie Comedy}} [[Category:21 Jump Street]] [[Category:2012 films]] [[Category:2010s action films]] [[Category:2010s buddy films]] [[Category:2010s high school films]] [[Category:2010s satirical films]] [[Category:American 3D films]] [[Category:American action comedy films]] [[Category:American buddy cop films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American high school films]] [[Category:American satirical films]] [[Category:Buddy comedy films]] [[Category:Columbia Pictures films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films scored by Mark Mothersbaugh]] [[Category:Films based on television series]] [[Category:Films directed by Phil Lord and Christopher Miller]] [[Category:Films shot in Louisiana]] [[Category:Films shot in New Orleans]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films]] [[Category:Police comedy films]] [[Category:Films about proms]] [[Category:Relativity Media films]] [[Category:Screenplays by Jonah Hill]] [[Category:Self-reflexive films]] [[Category:Original Film films]] [[Category:Buddy cop films]]

{{Redirect|♾|the symbol|Infinity symbol|and|Lemniscate|the mathematical concept|Infinity}} [[Image:Acid-free_paper_(symbol).svg|thumb|The acid-free-paper symbol.]]
'''Acid-free paper''' is [[paper]] that if infused in water yields a neutral or [[basic (chemistry)|basic]] [[pH]] (7 or slightly greater). It can be made from any [[cellulose fiber]] as long as the active acid pulp is eliminated during processing. It is also [[lignin]]- and [[sulfur]]-free.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20000914045052/http://www.history.pcusa.org/cong/acidpaper.html|title=Untitled Document|date=14 September 2000|publisher=}}</ref> Acid-free paper addresses the problem of [[Preservation (library and archival science)|preserving documents]] and [[Conservation (cultural heritage)|artwork]] for long periods.
== Overview == Paper made from wood-based pulp that has not had its [[lignin]] removed turns yellow, becomes brittle, and deteriorates over time.<ref>Teygeler, R. (2004). Preserving paper: Recent advances. In J. Feather. (Ed.),'' Managing preservation for libraries and archives: Current practice and future development.'' 90. Burlington: Ashgate. {{ISBN|0-7546-0705-4}}</ref> When exposed to light and/or heat, the molecules in the acidic paper will break down even faster.<ref>Arnold, B.R. (2002). [http://cool.conservation-us.org/byauth/arnold/astm-aging-research/index.html ASTM's Paper Aging Research Program]. Retrieved November 4, 2007, [https://web.archive.org/web/20011223104404/http://palimpsest.stanford.edu/byauth/arnold/astm-aging-research/ archive 2001-12-23]/</ref> Acidic [[wood-pulp paper]] became commonplace in the late 19th century, and in the 1930s [[William Barrow (chemist)|William Barrow]] (a chemist and librarian) published a report about the deterioration of acidic paper in the libraries.<ref>Cedzova, M. et al. (2006). Patents for Paper Deacidification. ''Restaurator: International Journal for the Preservation of Library and Archival Material,'' 27, 35.</ref> For fear of the gradual disintegration of written materials, measures have since been taken to improve the quality of paper.
During production, acid-free paper may be treated with a mild base (usually calcium or magnesium [[bicarbonate]]) to neutralize the natural [[acid]]s occurring in [[wood pulp]], and it may also be [[buffer (chemistry)|buffered]] to prevent the formation of additional acids (as may develop from the application of [[sizing]]).
The bicarbonate is added in excess, to supply the paper with an [[alkaline]] reserve to provide protection from further attack by acids remaining in the paper or supplied by the environment (e.g. atmospheric [[sulfur dioxide]]).<ref name=niso1992 /> The bicarbonate during drying loses [[carbon dioxide]] and water and is converted to [[calcium carbonate]] or [[magnesium carbonate]]. In order for paper to last at least 100 years it must have an alkaline reserve of 2% or more.<ref>Teygeler, R. (2004). Preserving paper: Recent advances. In J. Feather. (Ed.), ''Managing preservation for libraries and archives: Current practice and future development.'' 89. Burlington: Ashgate. {{ISBN|0-7546-0705-4}}</ref>
Today, much of the commercially produced paper is acid-free,<ref>Dahlo, R. (2000). The Rationale of permanent Paper. In W. Manning & V. Kremp (Eds.), ''IFLA Publications 91: A Reader in preservation and conservation.'' 59. Munchen: K. G. Saur. {{ISBN|3-598-21817-6}}.</ref> but this is largely the result of a shift from kaolin clay to precipitated calcium carbonate (PCC) as the main filler material in the pulp: PCC reacts with acids, and therefore requires the pulp to be chemically neutral or alkaline. The [[sizing]] additives mixed into the pulp and/or applied to the surface of the paper must also be acid-free.
Alkaline paper has a life expectancy of over 1,000 years for the best paper and 500 years for average grades.<ref>ASTM D 3290-00, "Standard Specification for Bond and Ledger Papers for Permanent Records", section 3.2.3.2 and Appendix X1</ref> The making of alkaline paper has several other advantages in addition to the preservation benefits afforded to the publications and documents printed on it. Because there are fewer corrosive chemicals used in making alkaline paper, the process is much easier on the machinery, reducing downtime and maintenance, and extending the machinery's useful life. The process is also significantly more environmentally friendly. Waste water and byproducts of the papermaking process can be recycled; energy can be saved in the drying and refining process; and alkaline paper can be more easily recycled.<ref>Lundeen, G.W. (1983) Preservation of paper based materials: Present and future research and developments in the paper industry. In K.L. Henderson and W.T. Henderson (eds) ''Conserving and preserving library materials (Papers presented at the Allerton Park Institute November 15–18, 1981)'': 73-88. Retrieved from http://hdl.handle.net/2142/459 </ref>
==Standards== {{globalize|section|date=December 2010}} The company [[Hercules Inc.|Hercules Incorporated]] developed the first alkaline sizing in the 1950s that made acid-free paper possible.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ideals.uiuc.edu/handle/2142/459 |title=Preservation of paper based materials: Present and future research and developments in the paper industry |publisher=www.ideals.uiuc.edu |author=Gerald W. Lundeen |accessdate=2009-06-25 }}</ref> Despite the advances in paper making and the identification of and concern around the brittle book problem, it took decades before the adoption of [[ANSI]] [[NISO]] Standard Z39.48-1984 - ''Permanence of Paper for Publications and Documents in Libraries'' in 1984. This voluntary standard covered pH value, tear resistance, alkaline reserve, and lignin thresholds for paper to last thousands of years and was developed to encourage the use of acid-free paper in library materials.<ref name=niso1992>{{cite web|url=http://www.niso.org/standards/resources/Z39-48-1992R2002.pdf|title=ANSI NISO Standard Z39.48-1992R2002|publisher=}}</ref> The development of the initial standard was a result of the work of the Council on Library Resources, which effectively lobbied ANSI to adopt the guidelines.<ref>Ward Brown, J. (May 1985). The Once and Future Book: The Preservation Crisis. Wilson Library Bulletin, 59, 591-6.</ref>
In 1986, Standards Committee II of [[NISO]] was established to expand Z39.48-1984 to develop standards for [[coated paper]], and was again called upon in 1988 to review and revise the standards for uncoated paper.
There are various standards for "acid-free" paper, with differing requirements. In some quarters, slightly-acidic paper having a pH between 6 and 7 is often also considered "acid-free".{{elucidate|date=May 2012}} Acid-free (alkaline) paper that additionally is ''uncoated'' and meets certain ''standards for folding and tearing'' is authorized by the [[American National Standards Institute]] (ANSI) to carry the following notice: "The paper used in this publication meets the minimum requirements of the American National Standard for Information Sciences—Permanence of Paper for Printed Library Materials, ANSI/NISO Z39.48-1992."
The objective of ANSI Z39.48-1992 "is to establish criteria for coated and uncoated paper to last several hundred years" under optimal conditions in libraries and archives.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://webstore.ansi.org/RecordDetail.aspx?sku=ANSI%2FNISO+Z39.48-1992+(R2002) |author=American National Standards Institute |title=Permanence of paper for publications and documents in libraries and archives |date=October 26, 1992 |publisher=NISO Press |accessdate=2009-06-24 }}</ref> The desired outcome of the standard is to reduce future preservation problems.
The scope of the standard is to cover publications and documents bought and maintained by libraries and archives. Such works include scholarly journals, periodicals, monographs, government documents, original documents, and significant works in fiction and non-fiction.
An equivalent international standard, ISO 9706, was published in 1994.<ref name=iso9706>Information and documentation – Paper for documents – Requirements for permanence. International Standard ISO 9706:1994, [[International Organization for Standardization]], Geneva.</ref>
Manufacturers of acid-free paper can indicate the compliance of their product with the test requirements of the ISO 9706 or ANSI Z39.48-1992 standards using a circled [[infinity symbol]] (Unicode code point 267E, ♾).<ref name=iso9706/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/ch01/ch01_sec035.html|title=The Chicago Manual of Style, 17th Edition|website=The Chicago Manual of Style Online}}</ref>
== Archival paper ==
'''Archival paper''' is an especially permanent, durable acid-free paper. Archival paper is meant to be used for publications of high legal, historical, or significant value. In the USA, such paper must also be approved in accordance with the ANSI standards.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.ifla.org/IV/ifla64/115-114e.htm |title=Standards for Permanent Paper |work=64th IFLA General Conference - Conference Programme and Proceedings |publisher=archive.ifla.org |author=Ivar A. L. Hoel |accessdate=2009-06-24 }}</ref> The international standard for "permanent" paper is ISO 9706 and for "archival" paper, the standard is ISO 11108.<ref>Dahlo, R. (2000). The Rationale of permanent Paper. In W. Manning & V. Kremp (Eds.), ''IFLA Publications 91: A Reader in preservation and conservation.'' 58. Munchen: K. G. Saur. {{ISBN|3-598-21817-6}}.</ref>
Often, [[cotton paper|cotton rag]] paper is used for archival purposes, as it is not made from wood-based pulp. Thus, "archival paper" is sometimes broken down into two categories: * '''Conservation-grade''' — acid-free, buffered paper made from wood-based pulp. * '''Archival-grade''' (also Museum-grade) — cotton rag paper made from cotton pulp.
==See also== *[[Mass deacidification]] *[[Paper chemicals]] *[[Preservation (library and archival science)]] *[[Slow fire]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{Commonscatinline|ISO 9706}} * [[ASTM]] D1994-07 Standard Test Method for Determination of Acid Numbers of Hot-Melt Adhesives * National Archives of Australia: [http://www.naa.gov.au/services/family-historians/looking-after/about-paper.aspx descriptions of permanent and archival paper]; archival quality [http://www.naa.gov.au/records-management/secure-and-store/physical-preservation/quality-trademark/index.aspx trademark] and [http://www.naa.gov.au/records-management/secure-and-store/physical-preservation/quality-trademark/register.aspx register of certified products] *[http://www.decalimpressions.com/company-info/faqs/paper-thickness.html 'Paper thickness cross reference guide'']
{{Paper}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox lighthouse | image_name = alcatraz lighthouse.jpg | caption = Alcatraz Island Lighthouse | location = [[Alcatraz Island]], [[San Francisco Bay]], [[California]], [[United States]] | coordinates = {{coord|37|49|34.5|N|122|25|19.8|W|region:US_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = United States San Francisco#California | relief = 1 | pushpin = lighthouse | pushpin_map_caption = Location of Alcatraz Island Light | yearbuilt = 1854 (first) | yearlit = 1909 (current) | automated = 1963 | yeardeactivated = | foundation = Masonry basement | construction = Reinforced concrete | shape = Tapered octagonal tower with balcony and lantern | marking = Unpainted tower, black lantern | height = {{convert|84|ft}} | focalheight = {{convert|214|ft}} | lens = Third order [[Fresnel lens]] (removed) | currentlens = DCB-24 aerobeacon | range = {{convert|22|nmi}} | characteristic = Fl W 5s. | admiralty = G4082 | ARLHS = USA-003 | USCG = 6-4315 | managingagent = Golden Gate National Recreation Area<ref>[https://www.unc.edu/~rowlett/lighthouse/ca.htm ] The Lighthouse Directory. University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Retrieved 9 June 2016</ref><ref>[http://www.uscg.mil/history/weblighthouses/LHCA.asp California Historic Light Station Information & Photography] United States Coast Guard. Retrieved 9 June 2016</ref> | module = {{Infobox NRHP | nocat = yes | embed = yes | nrhp_type = cp | designated_nrhp_type = June 23, 1976 | partof = [[Alcatraz]] | partof_refnum = 76000209<ref name="focus">{{Cite web |url=http://nrhp.focus.nps.gov |title=NPS Focus |work=National Register of Historic Places |publisher=[[National Park Service]] |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> }} }}
'''Alcatraz Island Lighthouse''' is a [[lighthouse]] – the first one built on the U.S. [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]] – located on [[Alcatraz Island]] in [[California]]'s [[San Francisco Bay]].<ref name =USGS>{{Cite GNIS|1809338|Alcatraz Island Lighthouse|September 10, 2012}}</ref> It is located at the southern end of the island near the entrance to the prison.<ref name="lighthousefriends.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.lighthousefriends.com/light.asp?ID=74|title=Alcatraz Island, CA|work=lighthousefriends.com|accessdate=10 September 2012}}</ref> The first light house on the island was completed in 1854, and served the bay during its time as a [[Alcatraz Citadel|Citadel]] and military prison. It was replaced by a taller ({{convert|95|ft}} above mean sea level) concrete tower built in 1909 to the south of the original one which was demolished after it was damaged due to [[earthquake]] in 1906. The automation of the lighthouse with a modern [[beacon]] took place in 1963, the year Alcatraz closed as the [[Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary]]. It is the oldest light station on the island with a modern beacon and is part of the museum on the island.<ref name =USGS/><ref name="lighthousefriends.com"/> Although when viewed from afar it easily looks the tallest structure on Alcatraz, it is actually shorter than the [[Alcatraz Water Tower]], but as it lies on higher ground it looks much taller.
==History== [[File:Alcatraz light original2.jpg|thumb|left|Original lighthouse]] [[File:USCGalcatraz2.JPG|thumb|left|Alcatraz Lighthouse, 1909, U.S. Coast Guard Archive]] Even though the [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Indians]] of the San Francisco area are stated to be the original settlers on the island (they collected eggs from the large flock of birds that regularly gathered there), Alcatraz got its name in 1775 only when [[Juan de Ayala]], a [[Spaniard]] was engaged to survey the harbor and the San Francisco Bay. Since he observed pelicans in large numbers on the island he named the island as "Isla de los Alcatraces" meaning the "Island of Pelicans". The island is separated from the main land by more than {{Convert|1|mi|km}}.<ref name=" Mcshane 1996">{{cite book|last= Mcshane|first= M.|title= Encyclopedia of American Prisons|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wlje5poN3IQC&pg=PA34|year=1996|publisher= Taylor & Francis |isbn=9780815313502|page=34}}</ref>
The [[gold rush]] and the inherent risk of the choppy waters of the west coast prompted the urgent need for establishing lighthouses. Congress recognized the need and passed suitable acts in the years 1851 and 1852 to build seven lighthouses on the West Coast to guide navigation.<ref name="lighthousefriends.com"/> The Baltimore firm of Gibbons and Kelly was awarded the contract to build seven lighthouses in California, at Alcatraz Island, [[Fort Point Light (California)|Fort Point]], [[Point Pinos Light|Point Pinos]], [[Point Loma Light (old)|Point Loma]], [[Farallon Island Light|Farallon Island]], and [[Humboldt Harbor Light|Humboldt Bay]], and one at [[Cape Disappointment Lighthouse|Cape Disappointment]] in [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington State]]. Equipment were shipped on Oriole, reached San Francisco on January 29, 1853. The Alcatraz Lighthouse was the first to be completed in July 1853, making it the oldest major navigational light on the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]]. However, the foundation for building the light house had begun much before the equipment reached San Francisco.<ref name="lighthousefriends.com"/>
[[File:Alcatraz Island at Sunset.jpg|thumb|right|Alcatraz Light at sunset]] In the original order placed for supply of the equipment Argand lamps and parabolic reflectors had been specified as the Fresnel lens, created by [[Augustin Fresnel]] of France in 1822 was considered very costly at that time. However, the Lighthouse Board which replaced the [[Fifth Auditor of the Treasury]]'s control, decided to install Fresnel lenses in all lighthouses considering its established better performance, even though the cost was high. The Baltimore firm was informed of this change before the equipment was shipped.<ref name="lighthousefriends.com"/> The shipping involved a long sea voyage of {{Convert|12000|mi|km}} from the East Coast going round the cape of [[South America]].<ref name=" Jones 2007">{{cite book|last= Jones |first= Ray |title= The Lighthouse Encyclopedia: The Definitive Reference |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=WQxxM-lZL4gC&pg=PA268|accessdate=10 September 2012|year=2007|publisher= Globe Pequot |isbn=978-0-7627-4578-4|pages=34, 87}}</ref> It was lit on June 1, 1854, from a fixed, third-order Fresnel lens. In 1902, it was transferred to the [[Cape St. Elias Lighthouse]] in Alaska and replaced by a revolving fourth-order Fresnel lens, producing a white flash every five seconds.<ref name="lighthousefriends.com"/>
In 1909–12, the present cell house of Alcatraz was built. Since the new structure would interfere with the operation of the lighthouse, a taller {{convert|25.6|m|ft}}, concrete tower was built south of the original lighthouse. The original lighthouse had been damaged during the great [[San Francisco earthquake of 1906]] and was eventually torn down. In 1963, the Alcatraz Lighthouse was automated by the [[United States Coast Guard]]. In 1970 a fire destroyed the warden's house, the keepers' quarters and other buildings on the island. The only remaining building is the tall cement tower equipped with a modern beacon. The lighthouse has been a museum since 2000 and can be visited.<ref name="lighthousefriends.com"/> In over 50 years, the lighthouse has not been seriously damaged despite many prison escapes, the [[Battle of Alcatraz]] and fires.<ref name="Light"/>
==Structural details== [[File:Alcatraz11.JPEG|thumb|left]] [[File:Alcatraz lighthouse in 2007.JPG|thumb|right|Alcatraz Lighthouse, 2007]] The first lighthouse was {{convert|50|ft|m}} in height, and was based on a design that was typical of early "[[Cape Cod style]]" lighthouses, in which the light tower was an integral part of the keeper's house, and was centered atop the dwelling's roof. Construction of the foundation started in 1852, and the one-and-a-half-storied keeper's house and light were completed in 1853. The lens arrived in October 1853 and Michael Cassin lit it on June 1, 1854, thus setting a "milestone" of sorts for this lighthouse, as the first lighthouse on the [[Pacific Coast]]. The old lighthouse was damaged in the earthquake which occurred on Wednesday the April 18, 1906. A new lighthouse was built to the south east of the old one. The old lighthouse existed alongside the new structure for a while and used as a storehouse, but was eventually demolished between 1912 and 1913.<ref name=" Champion Jr. 2012">{{cite book|last= Champion Jr.|first= Jerry Lewis |title= Alcatraz Unchained|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VQV5wM6qj1oC&pg=PA18|year=2012|publisher= AuthorHouse |isbn=9781468587531|page=188}}</ref>
The existing lighthouse is built to a height of {{convert|84|ft|m}},<ref name="lighthousefriends.com"/> {{convert|214|ft|m}} above sea level,<ref name=" Champion Jr. 2012"/> to the south of the original lighthouse. Its foundation is made of masonry while the octagonal pyramidal shaped tower is made of concrete. Initially, a third order Fresnel reflector was installed in 1854, and was replaced by a fourth order reflector in 1903. The foghorn bell was replaced by electronic Klaxon. Near the base of the tower was family accommodation also built to house three keepers and their families.<ref name="lighthousefriends.com"/><ref name="Light">{{cite web|url=http://www.uscg.mil/history/weblighthouses/LHCA.asp|title= Historic Light Station Information& Photography, California |work= Alcatraz Island Light|accessdate=10 September 2012}}</ref> Similar "Cape-cod style" lighthouses, encircling the thick light brick tower, were built at Point Loma in [[San Diego]], Point Pinos near [[Monterey, California|Monterey]] and also on the Southeast Farallon Island about {{convert|30|mi}} west of the San Francisco Strait.<ref name="Jones 2007"/> [[File:Alcatraz Light blueprint.jpg|thumb|left|Coastguard building blueprint]] There was also a telephone installed, in the 1930, in the keepers quarters (moved to the hall later) known to and accessed only by the keepers. When the Federal Penitentiary was established on the island more telephones were installed and was made accessible to others also.<ref name=" Champion Jr. 2012"/>
The lighthouse was operated and maintained by the keepers whose responsibility included operation of fog signals found located on the northern and southern tips of the island. The prison guards facilitated the keepers to blow the fog horns as they were in advantageous position stationed on the elevated watch towers; the guards who were in position to see "a bank of fog started to roll through the Golden Gate", would inform notify the keepers so that the fog horns could be activated.<ref name="lighthousefriends.com"/>
===Navigation aids=== The leading marks which guide the ships while entering the island are the lime point which is {{convert|2.5|mi}} east and the black point which is lime {{convert|1|mi}} north. The island itself is interspersed with several buildings and military towers. The highest point of the island is where the light house is located. Northwestern and southeastern tips of the island have small buildings which housed the fog signals (the electric horns were installed in small buildings known as "mid twentieth century foghorn shacks".<ref name=" Jones 2007"/>). The white light is shown by a grey tower flashes white that lasts for 0.5 seconds and eclipses' for 4.5 seconds and forming with the Fort Point light House a range for crossing the bar for the main ship. Fog signals are electric sirens, one on the southeast end sounding two blasts of 4 seconds duration, every 30 seconds while the one on the northwest end gives a single blast every 20 seconds of 5 seconds duration.<ref name="Survey1917">{{cite book|last= Survey|first= U.S. Coast and Geodetic |title= United States coast pilot: Pacific Coast. California, Oregon, and Washington|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CdhBAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA91|year=1817|publisher= G.P.O.,|isbn=9781468587531|pages=90–91}}</ref>
==Keepers== The three lighthouse keepers, known as "wickies", were dressed in prescribed formal uniforms which consisted of a "navy blue hat, sack coat, vest and trousers". Decorative buttons and insignia patches adorned their uniforms. The keepers worked on an eight-hour shift with the beacon lighted all through the year; during day time the lens was covered and protected from sun rays.<ref name=" Champion Jr. 2012"/>
The island's lighthouse keepers included:<ref name="lighthousefriends.com"/> * Michael Cassin (1853–1855) * John Sloan (1855–1856) * Underwhill Van Wagner (1856–1862) * Hartford Joy (1862–1872) * Amasa Bushnell (1872–1874) * William W. Scott (1874–1875) * John A. F. McFarland (1875–1878) * John T. Huie (1878–1882) * John A. F. McFarland (1882–1888) * Benjamin F. Leeds (1888–1905) * Henry W. Young (1905–1909) * James Anderson (1909 – at least 1912) * Frederick Arthur Harrington (1919–1938) was the keeper of both the light houses and remained as keeper till his death in 1938.<ref name=" Champion Jr. 2012"/> * Harry Davis (1938 – at least 1940) * Edward Schneider
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Alcatraz Light citadel Hopi.jpg|Hopi inmates and original light File:Alcatraz light original.jpg |Original lighthouse, c.1894 File:Alcatraz lighthouse top.jpg |Top of light File:Alcatraz light2.jpg|Viewed from inland File:Alcatraz lighton.jpg| Light on File:Alcatraz light3.jpg|Viewed from inland </gallery>
==See also== {{stack|{{Portal|California|Lighthouses}}}} * [[List of lighthouses in the United States]]

revision.text:
'''Arthur Kurzweil''' (born 1951) is an [[United States|American]] author, [[educator]], [[editing|editor]], writer, [[publisher]], and [[illusionist]].<ref name="njjn012507"> {{cite news | last = Rubin | first = Debra | title = Educator brings a magic touch to event on faith and spirituality | publisher = New Jersey Jewish News | date = 2007-01-25 | url = http://www.njjewishnews.com/njjn.com/012507/sxEducatorBringsAMagicTouch.html | accessdate = 2008-03-09}}</ref>
Kurzweil was born in [[New York City]]. He was raised in [[East Meadow, New York|East Meadow]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. He earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree from New College at [[Hofstra University]] in 1971 and a [[Master of Library and Information Science|Master of Library Science]] from [[Florida State University]] in 1972.
As a scholar-in-residence and guest speaker in synagogues and other [[Jew]]ish organizations in the United States, as well as through the books he has written on [[Judaism]], the [[Torah]], [[Kabbalah]], and Jewish [[Genealogy|genealogical]] research, Kurzweil's career has been focused around helping others to discover the Jewish tradition. During his 17-year tenure at Jason Aronson Publishers, he commissioned and published over 650 volumes of Jewish interest,<ref name="njjn012507"/> a substantial contribution to the contemporary English-language Jewish library. Kurzweil has also been editor-in-chief of the Jewish Book Club,<ref name="TJW2588"/> president of the Jewish Book Council, and editorial consultant for [[John Wiley & Sons|Jossey-Bass]].
Kurzweil's book ''From Generation to Generation: How to Trace Your Jewish Genealogy and Family History'' is considered to be a definitive introductory guide on the topic.{{citation needed|date=March 2010}} Kurzweil has also authored two books in the [[for Dummies]] series: ''Kabbalah for Dummies'' and ''The Torah for Dummies''. His other books are ''On the Road with Rabbi Steinsaltz'', ''The Encyclopedia of Jewish Genealogy'' and ''My Generations: A Course in Jewish Family History'', which is commonly used as a textbook at synagogue schools in the United States.
==Career==
===In literature===
====Author==== Kurzweil's interest in writing formed early in his childhood.<ref name="interview"/> His first article, "Today's Troubled Youth: A Teenager's View", was published at the age of 15. It first appeared in ''[[Newsday]]'' and became nationally syndicated. It was included in the weekly current events reading supplement then commonly used in public schools in the United States.<ref name="newsday19680127">{{cite news | last = Kurzweil | first = Arthur | work = Newsday | title = Today's Troubled Youth: A Teenager's View | date = 1968-01-27}}</ref>
Kurzweil spent ten years working as a [[freelance writer]], writing articles for numerous publications including [http://www.hadassahmagazine.org ''Hadassah''], ''National Jewish Monthly'', ''[[Moment Magazine]]'' and ''L.I.'' (''Newsday'''s Sunday magazine). He also contributed articles to ''The Jewish Almanac'' (1980), ''The Jewish Family Book: A Creative Approach to Raising Kids'' (1981), the three volumes comprising ''The Jewish Catalog'' ([[Jewish Publication Society]] in 1973, 1976 and 1980, a 1960's style compilation of [[do-it-yourself]] guides covering a wide range of topics of interest for Jewish people. Kurzweil contributed to articles about building a personal Jewish library, Judaica [[philately]], and Jewish genealogy.
His interest in genealogy coincided with the release of [[Alex Haley]]'s book ''[[Roots: The Saga of an American Family]]'' and ''Catching the Wave'' in 1976. He wrote "Past Shock: How One Man Took a Journey Back into His Family's History", a feature article for ''L.I.''. The publication of this article initiated his career as both a professional writer and a public speaker. His weekly column, ''Finding Jewish Roots'', appeared in ''The [[Jewish Week]]'', a Jewish newspaper in New York, in 1977 and 1978. In 1979, Kurzweil wrote a cover story for ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine, "Hizzoner's Roots", a genealogical study of former New York City Mayor [[Ed Koch]]'s past.<ref name="hizzoner">{{cite journal | last = Kurzweil | first = Arthur | journal = [[New York (magazine)|New York]] | title = Hizzoner's Roots | date = 1979-10-29}}</ref>
Motivated by his own confused and inconsistent treatment of New York City's numerous beggars, Kurzweil, in ''Brother, Can You Spare a Dime: The Treatment of Beggars According to Jewish Tradition'', poses 16 questions reflecting his ambivalence on accommodating their seemingly relentless requests for a handout. He then demonstrates how a relative novice can do research to find meaningful answers within the framework of the Jewish tradition.<ref name="tikumolam">{{cite web| url= http://www.usy.org/resources/publications/topubs.asp| title= Tikum Olam Publications List, United Synagogue Youth| accessdate= 2008-03-11| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080331044658/http://www.usy.org/resources/publications/topubs.asp| archivedate= 31 March 2008| deadurl= yes| df= }}</ref>
''From Generation to Generation: How to Trace Your Jewish Genealogy and Family History'' was first published in 1980 and has since been published in a third revised edition. The book provides information on Kurzweil's own family history quest in addition to step-by-step advice on gathering information on one's family history from family members, family papers, [[Holocaust]] research, immigration and naturalization records, and online databases, among other sources. A revised and updated version of this book was published by Jossey-Bass in 2004.
After an extended period of time during which Kurzweil's efforts were focused on publishing books by other authors, Kurzweil returned to his own writing, with books such as ''On the Road with Rabbi Steinsaltz: 25 Years of Pre-Dawn Car Trips, Mind-Blowing Encounters, and Inspiring Conversations with a Man of Wisdom'' in 2006, ''Kabbalah for Dummies'' in 2007 and ''The Torah for Dummies'' in 2008.
In 2009, Jossey-Bass published ''Pebbles of Wisdom From Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz: Edited and with Notes by Arthur Kurzweil''. It includes the internationally renowned rabbi's thoughts on the big topics of life and spirituality, culled from more than thirty years Rabbi Steinsaltz's lectures, writings, interviews, and conversations.
====Editor==== Kurzweil's credits as an editor include, ''Behold a Great Image: The Contemporary Jewish Experience in Photographs'' in 1978 co-edited with Sharon Strassfeld.<ref name="Behold"> {{cite book | last = Strassfield | first = Sharon | title = Behold a Great Image | publisher = Jewish Publication Society | year = 1978 | isbn = 978-0-8276-0105-5 }}</ref> The book which was awarded first prize for design at the Philadelphia Book Show,<ref name="JPSAR1980"> {{cite web | title = Jewish Publication Society Annual Report of 91st Year | publisher = The Jewish Publication Society of America | year = 1980 | url = http://www.ajcarchives.org/AJC_DATA/Files/1980_17_JPSAReport.pdf | format = [[PDF]] | accessdate = 2008-03-11}}</ref> was developed as a fundraising program by a Tzedekah Collective, a grassroots charitable fundraising initiative. The book was the culmination of a national photography project that aimed at capturing the modern Jewish experience. The top three winners received cash prizes, and the proceeds from the book were donated to charity.<ref name="introtojudaism">{{cite book |title= Introduction to Judaism: A Source Book |last= Einstein |first= Stephen J. |year= 1998 |publisher= Union for Reform Judaism |isbn= 0-8074-0649-X|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Other books Kurzweil has edited include ''The Strife of the Spirit'' in 1988, ''On Being Free'' in 1995 both written by Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz, ''Best Jewish Writing 2003'' and ''The [[Hadassah]] Jewish Family Book of Health and Wellness'' in 2006.
====Publisher==== From 1984 to 2001, Kurzweil acted as Editor-in-chief, publisher and Vice President at Jason Aronson Publishers<ref name="TJW2588"> {{cite news | last = Brawarsky | first = Sandee | title = Into The Mystic | work = [[The Jewish Week]] | date = 19 November 1999 | url = http://www.thejewishweek.com/viewArticle/c44_a2588/TheArts/Books.html | accessdate = 9 March 2008}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> during which time he published over 650 books on a wide range of topics pertaining to Jewish practice and belief. Notable authors that Kurzweil published include [[Adin Steinsaltz]], [[Elie Wiesel]], [[Shlomo Carlebach]], [[Aryeh Kaplan]], [[Joseph B. Soloveitchik]], and [[Zalman Schachter-Shalomi]]. From 2001 he has served as Judaica Consultant for Jossey-Bass.<ref name="bnaibrith51"/> Jewish book projects that Kurzweil develops for Jossey-Bass are imprinted with the words "An Arthur Kurzweil Book" on each book's title page.
===Educator=== {{quote|I am a Jewish educator; I just do it a little differently, that's all. My hope is to light a spark, to kindle a flame–for a love of Jewish learning–just as I have had for so much of my life. If people can laugh a little and enjoy themselves while they are learning, then I have done my job well. You may know about the Jewish custom of giving students a taste of honey along with their first formal lesson. According to our tradition, learning is supposed to be sweet.<ref name="interview">{{cite interview | last = Kurzweil | first = Arthur | interviewer = Alan Zoldan | title = Phone interview | date = 2008-01-16}}</ref> |Arthur Kurzweil}}
As a speaker, teacher, and scholar-in-residence, Kurzweil's teachings have covered various topics of Jewish interest, including the [[Talmud]], Kabbalah, and genealogy. His Kabbalah courses are frequently based upon the contemporary book by Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz, ''The Thirteen Petalled Rose: A Discourse on the Essence of Jewish Existence and Belief'', which he has claimed has had more influence on his life than any other book.<ref name="ontheroad">{{cite book | last = Kurzweil | first = Arthur | title = On the Road with Rabbi Steinsaltz: 25 Years of Pre-Dawn Car Trips, Mind-Blowing Encounters, and Inspiring Conversations with a Man of Wisdom | publisher = [[John Wiley & Sons|Jossey Bass]] | date = 1 September 2006 | pages = 304 | isbn = 978-0-7879-8324-6}}</ref>
Among the various forums at which Kurzweil has lectured and taught are Jewish educator conferences, such as the Conference for Alternatives in Jewish Education (CAJE), retreat centers, such as Elat Chayyim, The Aleph Society where he is the acting coordinator for the Talmud Circle Project, synagogues, schools, Jewish community centers, teacher conferences, and university groups, both in the United States and abroad. As a prolific lecturer and teacher, Kurzweil has been credited as "one individual who has made a major contribution to the resurgence in adult Jewish education.<ref name="JESNA12"> <!--PLEASE NOTE: THE "JOURNAL" AND "TITLE" ARE THE SAME AS THE TITLE IS NOT KNOWN AND A TITLE IS NEEDED. IF SOMEONE WHO KNOWS THE CORRECT INFORMATION WOULD PLEASE INSERT IT, THANK YOU--> {{cite journal | journal = Agenda: Jewish Education | issue = 12 | title = Agenda: Jewish Education | publisher = [[JESNA|Jewish Education Service of North America]] | year = 1999}}</ref>
===Genealogist=== Kurzweil co-founded the first Jewish Genealogical Society in 1977 and was co-publisher with Steven W. Siegel of ''Toledot: The Journal of Jewish Genealogy'' (1977–1982).<ref name="avotaynu">{{cite book | last = Sack | first = Sallyann Amadur |author2=[[Gary Mokotoff]] | title = Avotaynu Guide to Jewish Genealogy | publisher = [[Avotaynu]] | date = 2004-07-01 | isbn = 978-1-886223-16-5}}</ref> There are now over 80 Jewish Genealogical Societies worldwide.
In 1999, Kurzweil was honored with a Lifetime Achievement Award from the [[International Association of Jewish Genealogical Societies]] (IAJGS)<ref name="IAJGS">{{cite web |url= http://iajgs.org/awards_files/awards-1999.html | title= IAJGS Awards 1999 | publisher = International Association of Jewish Genealogical Societies | accessdate=2008-03-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080109012627/http://iajgs.org/awards_files/awards-1999.html |archivedate = 2008-01-09}}</ref> His commemorative plaque read:
"In deep appreciation of your trailblazing work which teaches us that learning about Jewish family history is possible, despite ages of community destruction, Diaspora and the Holocaust. We will always be grateful that you showed us the way, and for your past and continued inspiration to all Jewish genealogists and new Jewish genealogical societies that continue to be created worldwide because of your vision."
Kurzweil serves on the Honorary Advisory Board for the International Institute for Jewish Genealogy (IIJG)<ref name="IIJG">{{cite web |url=http://iijg.org.html |title=IIJG Honorary Advisory Board Member |publisher=International Institute for Jewish Genealogy |accessdate=2009-08-04 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and also heads a working group that is developing ethical standards for Jewish genealogy. The IIJG is committed to developing Jewish genealogy into a recognized academic discipline, within the realm of Jewish Studies and in association with a broad range of other sciences on an interdisciplinary basis.
===Magician=== Kurzweil was introduced to magic by his father who took him to a magic shop to help with a third grade school project.<ref name="tricksandtractates"> {{cite news | last = Lipman | first = Steve | title = Tricks and Tractates | publisher = [[The Jewish Week]] | date = 2004-05-27}}</ref> His first magic trick, one that transformed a penny into a dime, was purchased for him by his father. Kurzweil belongs to the [[Society of American Magicians]] as well as the [[International Brotherhood of Magicians]]. Inspired by [[Project Magic]], an effort to encourage physical therapists to use magic tricks as part of therapy founded by magician [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], Kurzweil has spent time teaching physical therapists how to use magic tricks as a rehabilitative tool.
Although the [[Torah]] and Jewish authorities specifically prohibits "supernatural magic", tricks which rely upon sleight-of-hand and misdirection to fool the eye are permitted. Since 2004, Kurzweil has performed a Jewish-themed magic show, "Searching for God in a Magic Shop", that combines magic tricks and illusions with a spiritual message. Of his presentation, Kurzweil states,
{{quote|It's not a magic show at all, but a discussion of one of the most profound and important ideas in all of Jewish thought. All that God does is for the good even though we, his human audience, may not see it—because we don't see everything. The audience doesn't see everything—that's the human predicament. Accepting the notion of "gam zu l'tovah" (an idiomatic [[Aramaic]] expression taught in the Talmud meaning "Everything is for the best") has transformed my life.<ref name="interview"/>}}
==Awards== * The Distinguished Humanitarian Award from the Melton Center for Jewish Studies at [[Ohio State University]].<ref name="bnaibrith51">{{cite web|title=Arthur Kurzweil |publisher=[[B'nai B'rith|B'nai B'rith International]] |url=http://www.bnaibrith.org/lbureau/full_bio.cfm?vs=51 |accessdate=2008-03-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061213222725/http://www.bnaibrith.org/lbureau/full_bio.cfm?vs=51 |archivedate=December 13, 2006 }}</ref> * Lifetime Achievement Award from the International Association of Jewish Genealogical Societies.<ref name="bnaibrith51"/><ref name="IAJGS"/> * [[Beta Phi Mu]], the international honor society for library & information science and information technology.<ref name="betaphimu">{{cite web | url= http://www.beta-phi-mu.org/ | title= Beta Phi Mu home page}}</ref>
==Bibliography== * ''The Kurzweil Family History and Genealogy'' (1976) * ''Behold a Great Image: The Contemporary Jewish Experience in Photographs'' (Co-editor) (1978) * ''My Generations: A Course in Jewish Family History'' (1984) * {{cite book|editor1-last=Kurzweil|editor1-first=Arthur|editor2-last=Weiner|editor2-first=Miriam|title=The Encyclopedia of Jewish Genealogy|date=1991|publisher=J. Aronson|location=Northvale, NJ|isbn=978-0-87-668835-9|oclc=609144865}} * ''Words to Live by: Selected Writings'' (Editor) (1995) * ''Best Jewish Writing'' (Editor) (2003) * ''From Generation to Generation: How to Trace Your Jewish Genealogy and Family History'' (2004) * ''On the Road with Rabbi Steinsaltz: 25 Years of Pre-Dawn Car Trips, Mind-Blowing Encounters, and Inspiring Conversations with a Man of Wisdom'' (2006) * ''Kabbalah For Dummies (2007) * ''The Torah For Dummies'' (2008) * ''Pebbles of Wisdom from Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz: Collected and with Notes by Arthur Kurzweil'' (2009)
==Articles== * [http://www.webheights.net/speakingcohen/jewish.htm "A Conversation with [[Leonard Cohen]]"]{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The Jewish Book News (1994) * [http://www.steinsaltz.org/dynamic/essay_details.asp?id=37&sub=1 "A Conversation about Jewish Spirituality with Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz"] Jewish Spirituality: The Magazine, (January 2004) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070809210745/http://www.ziv.org/begging_kurzweil.doc "Brother, Can You Spare a Dime? The Treatment of Beggars According to Jewish Tradition"] Gym Shoes and Irises by [[Danny Siegel]] (Town Press, 1987) * [http://www.zchor.org/KURZ.HTM "Genealogy as a Spiritual Pilgrimage"] from the Malcolm R. Stern Memorial Lecture given at the 14th Summer Seminar on Jewish Genealogy, Washington, DC, (June 28, 1995) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081120213145/http://www.arthurkurzweil.com/downloads/Project%20Magic%20article.pdf "Project Magic"] Genii: The Conjurors' Magazine, (Vol. 66, No. 1, January 2003)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.arthurkurzweil.com Official website] * [http://www.spiritualityandpractice.com/books/books.php?id=16110 ''On the Road with Rabbi Steinsaltz'' book review] * [http://www.jewishsf.com/content/2-0-/module/displaystory/story_id/32695/format/html/edition_id/606/displaystory.html "Reflections on an association with a talmudic scholar"] * [http://www.jbooks.com/nonfiction/index/NF_Michaelson_Kurzweil.htm "Adin Steinsaltz and his Faithful, Driving Boswell" book review] * [http://www.jewishreview.org/node/11089 "Scholar’s expertise includes magic, genealogy, Talmud"] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070830082048/http://www.huc.edu/libblog/2006_10_01_archive.html "Too Good to Miss #3"]

{{Infobox book |name=Cefu Yuangui |subject=mainly politics and history |country=[[Song dynasty]] |pub_date=1013 |language=[[Classical Chinese]] |editor=[[Wang Qinruo]], [[Yang Yi (Song dynasty)|Yang Yi]] et al. }} {{Chinese|t={{linktext|冊|府|元|龜}}|s={{linktext|册|府|元|龟}}|p=Cèfǔ Yuánguī|l=Prime Tortoise of the Book Department}} '''''Cefu Yuangui''''' is the largest ''[[leishu]]'' (encyclopedia) compiled during the [[History of China|Chinese]] [[Song Dynasty]] ({{sc|ad}} 960–1279). It was the last of the ''[[Four Great Books of Song]]'', the previous three encyclopedias published in the 10th century.
==Name== English titles for this encyclopedia are * ''Prime Tortoise of the Record Bureau'',<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ugbWH-5OjegC&lpg=PA35&dq=%22Cefu%20Yuangui%22%20-wikipedia&pg=PA15#v=onepage&q=%22Cefu%20Yuangui%22%20-wikipedia&f=false |page=15 |title=Multicultural China in the Early Middle Ages |author=Chen Sanping |year=2012 |publisher=[[University of Pennsylvania Press]] |accessdate=August 9, 2014 |chapter=Chapter 1 }} This Wikipedia article was created in 2006 and renamed in 2006 as ''Prime Tortoise of the Record Bureau''.</ref> * ''The Magic Mirror in the Palace of Books'',<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AWLMQFiNh3oC&lpg=PA248&dq=%22Cefu%20Yuangui%22%20-wikipedia&pg=PA248#v=onepage&q=%22Cefu%20Yuangui%22%20-wikipedia&f=false |title=The Rebel Den of Nung Tri Cao: Loyalty and Identity along the Sino-Vietnamese Frontier |year=2007 |publisher=University of Washington Press |page=248 |first=James |last=Anderson |accessdate=August 9, 2014 |isbn=978-9971-69-367-1 }}</ref> * ''Archival Palace as the Great Oracle'',<ref>{{cite book |title=Mirroring the Past: The Writing and Use of History in Imperial China |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wN99fsHpbTsC&lpg=PA295&dq=%22Cefu%20Yuangui%22%20-wikipedia&pg=PA295#v=onepage&q=%22Cefu%20Yuangui%22%20-wikipedia&f=false |author1=Ng On-cho |author2-first=Q. Edward |author2-last=Wang |year=2005 |publisher=University of Hawai'i Press |accessdate=August 9, 2014 }}</ref> * ''General Preface on Outer Ministers'',<ref>{{cite book |title=The New Chinese Empire: And What It Means for the United States |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TKowRrrz5BIC&lpg=PA287&dq=%22Cefu%20Yuangui%22%20-wikipedia&pg=PA287#v=onepage&q=%22Cefu%20Yuangui%22%20-wikipedia&f=false |page=287 |first=Ross |last=Terrill |year=2003 |accessdate=August 9, 2014 |isbn=978-0-465-08412-8 }}</ref> * ''Outstanding Models from the Storehouse of Literature'',<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oGU-AwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA188&dq=%22Cefu%20Yuangui%22%20-wikipedia&pg=PA188#v=onepage&q=%22Cefu%20Yuangui%22%20-wikipedia&f=false |journal=The Journal of Korean Studies |volume=11 |editor1-first=John |editor1-last=Duncan |editor2=Shin Gi-Wook |first=Richard D II |last=McBride |title=Is the ''Samguk yusa'' reliable? |date=Fall 2006 |number=1 |accessdate=August 9, 2014 }}</ref> and * ''Models from the Archives''.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fROhAQAAQBAJ&lpg=PA511&dq=%22Cefu%20Yuangui%22%20-wikipedia&pg=PA511#v=onepage&q=%22Cefu%20Yuangui%22%20-wikipedia&f=false |title= Encyclopædism from Antiquity to the Renaissance |editor1-first=Jason |editor1-last=König |editor2-first=Greg |editor2-last=Woolf |chapter=Fifteen hundred years of the Chinese encyclopedia |author-first=Harriet T |author-last=Zurndorfer |year=2013 |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |location=[[Cambridge]] |accessdate=August 9, 2014 }}</ref>
The encyclopedia was originally named ''Narrative of Monarchs and Officials in the Past Dynasties'' but was later renamed to ''Yuangui'', meaning the [[Oracle bone|oracle tortoise shells]], and ''Cefu'', the imperial's storehouse of [[literature]]. The work was started in 1005 and finished in 1013 by [[Wang Qinruo]] and numerous other scholars. It was one of the four books that were divided into 1,000 volumes. It was almost twice as large as the ''[[Imperial Reader of the Taiping Era]]'' and was ranked second in the ''[[Siku Quanshu]]'' collections. It consisted of about 9.4 million words (or [[Chinese characters]]), which included many political [[essay]]s, [[biographies]] of rulers and subjects, [[Memorandum|memorial]]s, and [[decree]]s.{{fact|date=February 2016}}
==See also== * [[Chinese literature]] * [[Chinese classic texts]] * [[Culture of the Song Dynasty]]
==References== ===Citations=== {{reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== *Hu, Wenjie, [https://web.archive.org/web/20070929100046/http://203.72.198.245/web/Content.asp?ID=50913&Query=1 ''Cefu Yuangui'' ("Prime Tortoise of the Record Bureau")].{{dead link|date=March 2011}} ''[[Encyclopedia of China]]'', 1st ed. *Kurz, Johannes. "The Compilation and Publication of the ''Taiping Yulan'' and the ''Cefu Yuangui''", in Florence Bretelle-Establet and [[Karine Chemla]] (eds.), Qu'est-ce qu'écrire une encyclopédie en Chine?. Extreme Orient-Extreme Occident Hors série (2007), 39-76.
==External links== * [http://www.chinaknowledge.de/Literature/Science/cefuyuangui.html ''Cefu yuangui'' "The Prime Tortoise of the Record Bureau"] — Chinaknowledge.de.
